title: The Haber process

multiple-choice.question: What is the most important discovery made in the past few centuries, according to the speaker?

options.label: C
options.text: The Haber process of binding nitrogen molecules in the air to hydrogen molecules

options.label: A
options.text: To produce ammonia for industrial and household cleaners

options.label: B
options.text: To create a new method for fertilization

options.label: C
options.text: To bind nitrogen molecules in the air to hydrogen molecules to produce ammonia

options.label: D
options.text: To decompose ammonia back into nitrogen and hydrogen

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To allow the reaction to reach a point where the ammonia molecules start to decompose back into the nitrogen and hydrogen

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the pressure on the equilibrium system

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the amount of ammonia in the atmosphere

options.label: C
options.text: It damages the environment by releasing volatile chemical compounds into the Earth's water supplies and atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the environment

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the production of ammonia

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the amount of nitrogen in the air

options.label: C
options.text: To find a new Haber process of the 21st century that will reach the same level of aid without the dangerous consequences

options.label: D
options.text: To decompose ammonia back into nitrogen and hydrogen

options.label: A
options.text: Only negatively charged particles called electrons

options.label: B
options.text: Only positively charged particles called protons

options.label: C
options.text: At least one positively charged particle called a proton, and in most cases, some number of neutral particles called neutrons

multiple-choice.question: How do we know about atomic structure?

options.label: A
options.text: By directly observing protons, neutrons, and electrons

options.label: B
options.text: By doing experiments and developing a model for what we think is there

options.label: C
options.text: By using a combination of experiments and direct observation

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why chemists love electrons?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are free to move

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can be used to make new compounds

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are easy to observe

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the shapes that describe the probability of finding an electron in a given space around the nucleus?
What determines the shape of an orbital?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of protons in the nucleus

options.label: C
options.text: The number of neutrons in the nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: The number of electrons in the orbital

multiple-choice.question: Why did we pick 95% as the probability of finding an electron in a given space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the maximum possible probability

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is the minimum possible probability

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a quirk of our model of the electron

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a random choice

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the probability of finding an electron as it moves away from the nucleus?
What determines the dynamics of the social network of atoms?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of protons in the nucleus

options.label: B
options.text: The number of electrons in the orbital

options.label: C
options.text: The interaction of electrons from one atom with electrons from another

options.label: D
options.text: The number of neutrons in the nucleus

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why chemistry is interesting?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the complexity of life

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the nature of everything we see, hear, smell, taste, touch, and feel

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the dynamics of the social network of atoms

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the simplicity of chemical reactions

multiple-choice.question: What is determined at the atomic level?

options.label: A
options.text: The nature of everything we see, hear, smell, taste, touch, and feel

options.label: B
options.text: The number of protons in the nucleus

options.label: C
options.text: The number of electrons in the orbital

options.label: D
options.text: The number of neutrons in the nucleus

title: Mosquitos, malaria and education - Bill Gates

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of the foundation's work, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce the number of deaths caused by malaria

options.label: B
options.text: To improve the education system in the United States

options.label: C
options.text: To draw more people in to work on important problems that don't get enough attention

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new vaccines for diseases

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the speaker's optimism about solving complex problems?

options.label: A
options.text: Because governments and private sectors are naturally inclined to solve these problems

options.label: B
options.text: Because the speaker is an expert in the field

options.label: C
options.text: Because of past successes in solving problems like malaria and childhood deaths

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the availability of resources

multiple-choice.question: What is the main cause of malaria deaths, according to the speaker?

options.label: C
options.text: The parasite evolves and the mosquito evolves

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's plan to eradicate malaria?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new vaccines and distribute them worldwide

options.label: B
options.text: To kill mosquitoes with DDT and treat patients with quinine

options.label: C
options.text: To use a combination of tools, including bed nets, indoor spraying, and new drugs

options.label: D
options.text: To rely on the market to drive the solution

multiple-choice.question: What is the main obstacle to eradicating malaria, according to the speaker?

options.label: C
options.text: The disease is only in poor countries, so it doesn't get enough investment

options.label: D
options.text: The parasite evolves and the mosquito evolves

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's plan to make education better?

options.label: C
options.text: To identify and replicate the characteristics of top-performing teachers

options.label: D
options.text: To rely on the market to drive the solution

multiple-choice.question: What is the main characteristic of top-performing teachers, according to the speaker?

options.label: C
options.text: They are able to engage students and tailor their teaching to individual needs

options.label: D
options.text: They are paid more than other teachers

multiple-choice.question: What is the main obstacle to making education better, according to the speaker?

options.label: C
options.text: The education system is not designed to reward and retain top-performing teachers

options.label: D
options.text: The disease is only in poor countries, so it doesn't get enough investment

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's plan to identify and replicate the characteristics of top-performing teachers?

options.label: C
options.text: To use digital video to record and analyze teaching practices

options.label: D
options.text: To rely on the market to drive the solution

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the speaker's talk, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: That governments and private sectors are naturally inclined to solve complex problems

options.label: B
options.text: That the speaker is optimistic about solving complex problems

options.label: C
options.text: That the key to solving complex problems is to identify and replicate the characteristics of top-performing teachers and to use a combination of tools to solve the problem

options.label: D
options.text: That the disease is only in poor countries, so it doesn't get enough investment

title: Why I'm a weekday vegetarian - Graham Hill

multiple-choice.question: What motivated the speaker to question their meat consumption about a year ago?

options.label: C
options.text: A concern for animal welfare and the environment

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's initial hesitation in adopting a vegetarian diet?

options.label: A
options.text: The high cost of meat alternatives

options.label: B
options.text: The lack of variety in plant-based options

options.label: C
options.text: A binary solution that didn't allow for flexibility

options.label: D
options.text: A fear of trying new foods

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the speaker's flexible diet plan that combines vegetarianism with occasional meat consumption?
According to the speaker, what are the major culprits in terms of environmental damage and health?
What is the approximate percentage of meat intake reduction that the speaker achieved by following their diet plan?
What are some benefits that the speaker experienced as a result of adopting their diet plan?

options.label: B
options.text: Healthier eating habits and reduced pollution

options.label: C
options.text: Increased meat consumption and higher healthcare costs

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced animal welfare and environmental concerns

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of animals raised for meat each year?
According to the speaker, what would be the impact of reducing meat consumption by half?

options.label: A
options.text: It would be like half of us were vegetarian

options.label: C
options.text: It would increase healthcare costs by 20%

options.label: D
options.text: It would have no significant impact

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in promoting their diet plan?

options.label: A
options.text: To convince everyone to become vegetarian

options.label: C
options.text: To encourage people to take small steps towards healthier eating

options.label: D
options.text: To increase meat production and consumption

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's motivation for promoting their diet plan?

options.label: A
options.text: To make money from selling meat alternatives

options.label: C
options.text: To promote environmental sustainability and personal health

options.label: D
options.text: To increase meat consumption and reduce healthcare costs

title: Why don’t oil and water mix? - John Pollard

multiple-choice.question: What are the two main reasons why anything happens at all, according to the transcript?
What is the primary focus of energetics in the context of the transcript?
What is the name of the constant and random dance that water molecules engage in?
What is the main reason why salt dissolves in water?

options.label: A
options.text: The attractive forces between salt and water molecules

options.label: B
options.text: The repulsive forces between salt and water molecules

options.label: C
options.text: The random motion of salt molecules

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why oil doesn't mix with water?

options.label: A
options.text: The attractive forces between oil and water molecules

options.label: B
options.text: The repulsive forces between oil and water molecules

options.label: D
options.text: The random motion of oil molecules

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the role of entropy in the context of mixing?

options.label: C
options.text: Entropy has no role in mixing

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the way water molecules and oil molecules in the context of the dance?

options.label: A
options.text: Water molecules are smaller than oil molecules

options.label: B
options.text: Water molecules are larger than oil molecules

options.label: C
options.text: Water molecules are good dancers, while oil molecules are not

options.label: D
options.text: Oil molecules are good dancers, while water molecules are not

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the addition of salt ions to the water?

options.label: A
options.text: The salt ions disrupt the hydrogen bonding network

options.label: B
options.text: The salt ions are repelled by the water molecules

options.label: C
options.text: The salt ions are attracted to the water molecules and join the dance

options.label: D
options.text: The salt ions have no effect on the water molecules

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why oil molecules are not good dancers?

options.label: C
options.text: They are not attracted to the water molecules

options.label: D
options.text: They are not repelled by the water molecules

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the interaction between water molecules and oil molecules?

options.label: A
options.text: The water molecules and oil molecules mix together

options.label: B
options.text: The water molecules and oil molecules separate

options.label: C
options.text: The water molecules and oil molecules form a new substance

options.label: D
options.text: The water molecules and oil molecules have no effect on each other

title: The science of stage fright (and how to overcome it) - Mikael Cho

multiple-choice.question: What is the natural response that humans experience when they perceive a threat, such as public speaking?
According to Charles Darwin, what was his response to the snake exhibit at the London Zoo?

options.label: A
options.text: He was not affected by the snakes

options.label: B
options.text: He was very calm and collected

options.label: C
options.text: His will and reason were powerless against the imagination of a danger

options.label: D
options.text: He was not interested in the snakes

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the hypothalamus in the fight or flight response?

options.label: B
options.text: To trigger the pituitary gland to secrete the hormone ACTH

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of adrenaline on the body during the fight or flight response?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the body to relax

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the heart rate to slow down

options.label: C
options.text: It causes the muscles to tense up

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the body to sweat

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a way to reduce anxiety when speaking in public?

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on the fear of being seen as an awful idiot

options.label: B
options.text: To practice a lot in an environment similar to the real performance

options.label: C
options.text: To try to overcome the natural fight or flight response

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the fear and just speak

multiple-choice.question: Who is an example of someone who practiced extensively before speaking in public?
What is the role of the pituitary gland in the fight or flight response?

options.label: B
options.text: To trigger the hypothalamus to secrete the hormone ACTH

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the fight or flight response on the digestive system?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the body to digest food more efficiently

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the body to shut down digestion to maximize the delivery of nutrients and oxygen to muscles and vital organs

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the digestive system

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the body to feel hungry

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how can you trick your brain into feeling more relaxed before speaking in public?

options.label: A
options.text: By taking deep breaths and stretching your arms up

options.label: B
options.text: By focusing on the fear of being seen as an awful idiot

options.label: C
options.text: By trying to overcome the natural fight or flight response

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the fear and just speaking

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of adapting to the fight or flight response when speaking in public?

options.label: B
options.text: To ignore the fear and just speak

options.label: C
options.text: To convince the crowd that you are a charismatic genius

options.label: D
options.text: To adapt to the natural response and use it to your advantage

title: Why extremophiles bode well for life beyond Earth - Louisa Preston

multiple-choice.question: What field of study combines physics, biology, astronomy, and geology to investigate the possibility of life in the universe?
What are the three basic things that organisms on Earth need to survive?

options.label: A
options.text: Liquid water, a source of energy, and oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Liquid water, a source of energy, and organic, carbon-based material

options.label: C
options.text: Liquid water, organic, carbon-based material, and high pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Liquid water, a source of energy, and high temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the NASA rover that is exploring places where life might once have existed on Mars?
What is the name of the impact crater created when a meteor hit the surface of Mars nearly 3.8 billion years ago?
Which of the following moons of Jupiter has a liquid ocean beneath its shell?
What is the composition of the rivers on Titan, one of Saturn's moons?

options.label: B
options.text: Liquid hydrocarbons such as methane and ethane

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the type of organisms that can survive in extreme environments?
Why are astrobiologists studying the Earth's natural laboratory to learn about all the weird and wonderful forms of life?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the diversity of life on Earth

options.label: C
options.text: To study the evolution of life on Earth

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the origins of life on Earth

multiple-choice.question: What is the main question that astrobiologists are trying to answer?

options.label: A
options.text: Are we alone in the universe?

options.label: C
options.text: How did life originate on Earth?

options.label: D
options.text: What is there life on Mars?

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of finding life on other planets or moons in our solar system?

options.label: A
options.text: It would prove the existence of God

options.label: B
options.text: It would provide evidence of the possibility of life beyond Earth

options.label: C
options.text: It would show that life is unique to Earth

options.label: D
options.text: It would disprove the theory of evolution

title: Can we eat to starve cancer? - William Li

multiple-choice.question: How many miles worth of blood vessels are in a typical adult human body?
What is the name of the process by which the human body grows blood vessels?
What is the primary function of angiogenic factors?

options.label: A
options.text: To inhibit the growth of blood vessels

options.label: B
options.text: To stimulate the growth of blood vessels

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for cancer without a blood supply?
What is the name of the experimental drug used to treat glioma, a type of brain tumor?
According to the speaker, what percentage of men in their 50s and 60s have microscopic prostate cancers?
What is the name of the substance found in tomatoes that is anti-angiogenic?
What is the name of the insurance company that has already begun to think about the implications of dietary cancer prevention?

options.label: A
options.text: Blue Cross Blue Shield of Minnesota

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what percentage of men who consumed cooked tomatoes two to three times a week had a 50% reduction in their risk of developing prostate cancer?
What is the name of the researcher who is collaborating with the speaker to study the role of a healthy diet on markers of angiogenesis?

title: Toward a science of simplicity - George Whitesides

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's approach to discussing simplicity?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a comprehensive definition of simplicity

options.label: B
options.text: To share their expertise on the topic

options.label: C
options.text: To share their ignorance on the topic and explore different perspectives

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on the complexity of simplicity

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main characteristic of simplicity?

options.label: B
options.text: It is a system with many components

options.label: C
options.text: It is a system with a simple function and a complex construction

options.label: D
options.text: It is a system that is difficult to understand

multiple-choice.question: What is the example of simplicity that the speaker uses to illustrate the concept of stacking?
What is the key characteristic of binary that makes it a simple system?

options.label: B
options.text: It is a system with many components

options.label: C
options.text: It is a system that can represent numbers in a simple and unambiguous way

options.label: D
options.text: It is a system that is difficult to understand

multiple-choice.question: What is the example of a simple device that the speaker uses to illustrate the concept of stacking?

options.label: D
options.text: A paper chip for medical diagnosis

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of the speaker's work in delivering healthcare in the developing world?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide expensive medical care to those who can afford it

options.label: B
options.text: To provide medical care at zero cost to those who need it

options.label: D
options.text: To improve the healthcare system in the US

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key characteristic of simple things?

options.label: B
options.text: They are systems with many components

options.label: C
options.text: They are systems that are predictable, cheap, and have the potential to serve as building blocks

options.label: D
options.text: They are systems that are difficult to understand

multiple-choice.question: What is the example of a system that the speaker uses to illustrate the concept of complexity?
According to the speaker, what is the key to achieving simplicity in design?

options.label: C
options.text: Making the system more complex and difficult to understand

options.label: D
options.text: Making the system more expensive and less functional

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in developing a science of simplicity?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a comprehensive definition of simplicity

options.label: C
options.text: To help people understand how to make things as simple as possible, as cheap as possible, as functional as possible, and as freely interconnectable as possible

options.label: D
options.text: To improve the healthcare system in the US
